prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have APEX data of the main ridge of NGC 6334 in HCN(3-2). Non-LTE calculations of the protostellar cluster NGC 6334I(N) (which is representative for the other cluster cores) provide average peak line flux densities of 0.5 Jy/beam in H13CN(4-3) when simulating the observations with CASA (assuming core densities of 10^6-10^7 cm ́3 , a relative abundance for HCN of 10^-́8 and including thermal and phase noise) and peak continuum flux densities in the order of 0.1 Jy/beam at 350 GHz. With the capabilities of ALMA it will be possible to obtain high-angular resolution maps with very good sensitivity in short integration times, and we convinced ourselves with the simulations that the uv-coverage is sufficient in these short observations to provide an adequate image quality. Because all cores are extended up to 10 arcsec, the ACA will be needed. The 13 targets are covered by individual mosaics (40 s integration time per pointing, 3-5 min on-source time per target) and have a sky separation of less than 3 degrees. The estimated total time for all sources with the 12m-array is 2.1 h. Frequency and Correlator setup: The spectral setup contains four basebands in band 7, where the LSB ranges from 342-346 GHz and the USB from 354-358 GHz. In the USB, one baseband is centered at the center frequency of HCN and the other baseband is set in continuum mode. In the LSB, transitions of CO, H13CN, HC15N, CS and H2CS are covered (Table 1). The typical linewidth of all cores is 2 km/s, and we choose a velocity resolution of 0.12 km/s to sample the spectral line profile of HCN, and a lower velocity resolution of 0.42 km/s in the LSB. As we want to cover a broad bandwidth, we chose single polarization to get a larger number of spectral channels. The slightly higher data rate of 13.8 MB/s is needed to cover many different molecular tracer as discussed in the scientific justification. Some sources may contain line rich hot cores, so that the 4th baseband is set in TDM mode, giving at least 2 GHz bandwidth for the continuum. Imaging requirements: With a synthesized beam of 0.62 in the C34-2 configuration and a field of view of 17.52'' , the largest angular scale that can be mapped is 7.62 . This scale is about 0.06 pc and does not cover all cores with one single pointing, therefore we set up mosaics of 5-7 pointings (Nyquist-sampled) per target. The typical core sizes and distances between them are about 2”. Thus sub-arcsec resolution will be needed do distinguish them. The ACA (with a field of view of 302 , corresponding to 0.25 pc) is needed to recover the extended emission in all clusters. Requested sensitivity: Russeil et al. (2010) and Munoz et al. (2007) report typical peak continuum fluxes at 250 GHz of around 1 Jy/beam for the most massive cores, see Table 2. With the much smaller beam of ALMA the peak flux densities are expected to be in the order of 0.1-0.01 Jy/beam for the +selected sources. Russeil et al. (2010) give line intensities in the range of Tmb=1-10 K for HCO and HCN (J=1-0), which is comparable to our APEX observations in HCN(3-2) (Fig. 1c)). This order of magnitude in line intensities is expected as lower limits when observing with ALMA, since it is known that the emission is not broadly distributed but comes from compact sources. Therefore, to have a good signal-to-noise ratio, a sensitivity of less than 1 K is needed. With a desired angular resolution of 0.62'', the ALMA Observing Tool gives a rms of 46 mJy/beam at a velocity resolution of 0.42 km/s and 0.73 mJy/beam in the continuum in a bandwidth of 2 GHz. As recommended by the help desk, we put the 13 targets in one science goal, which results in an overestimation of the sensitivity given in the OT. When taking 7 overlapping pointings into account for one target (by using a ’rectangular field’ instead of a ’custom mosaic’ in the OT), the rms will be 28 mJy/beam at a velocity resolution of 0.42 km/s and 0.45 mJy/beam in the continuum.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe a sample of the most massive (100-1000 solar masses) cores in the filaments of the nearby high-mass star-forming complex NGC 6334/NGC 6357. A 7.5 GHz wide spectral window at 350 GHz offers a suitable combination of tracers of dense and warm gas (HCN(4-3)+isotopologues, CO(3-2), CS(7-6), H2CS) to give an insight into the cores’ morphology at 0.6” resolution. We aim to study the infall and outflow motions and mass fragmentation of the selected cores, which cover multiple evolutionary stages at similar environmental conditions. As previous studies have shown for the brightest sources NGC 6334I & I(N), interferometric observations reveal the fragmentation into several (hot) cores on scales of 1” (1700 AU). Comparable data for the weaker sources can only be obtained with the capabilities of ALMA. The filaments have been mapped on larger scales with APEX in 13CO(2-1), and the combination will allow us to probe the connection between the filament and the clusters by tracing the velocity field and the density and temperature distribution. We will analyze the data using well-established 3D radiative transfer methods, and compare them with star formation simulations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2013.1.00270.S, Early stages of high-mass cluster formation in NGC 6334I & I(N), Alexander Zernickel
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00098.S, Characterization of a statistical sample of high-mass cores in the NGC 6334 star forming region, Alexander Zernickel 2011, High-Mass Star Formation in NGC6334 - A First In-Depth ALMA View, Dariusz Lis
